nodes.text: Preferences that maximize the long-run time-average growth rate of wealth can be axiomatized and represented by a unique ergodic transformation of stochastic wealth processes
Ergodicity Economics claims agents maximize time-average growth and that appropriate ergodic transformations map between utility functions and stochastic processes
Define stochastic wealth process (SWP) x = {xt}t on filtered probability space with preferences over X, and define sample, time-average and expected growth rates for transformations of xt
Standard preference axioms (consistency, Archimedean, independence, monotonicity) on mixture space X imply existence of a linear functional L representing the preorder (Mixture Space Theorem)
Add Ergodicity Axiom (EA): ranking of two SWPs is by their asymptotic time-average growth rates of a transformation f, i.e., comparisons use lim t->infinity (f(xt)-f(x0))/t
Illustrative calculation: for multiplicative log-normal dynamics xt = exp(g t + sigma epsilon), f(xt)=ln xt yields identical time-average and expected growth rates while f(xt)=xt does not
Main theorem (Ergodic vNM): Axioms 3.1-3.5 are equivalent to (1) x âª° x' iff E[f(xt)] >= E[f(x't)] and (2) E[f(xt)] = lim t->infinity (f(xt)-f(x0))/t, so f is the ergodic transformation

Given a continuous-time Ito dynamic dx = a(x) dt + b(x) dW, an ergodic transformation f exists if df = alpha dt + beta dW with constant alpha,beta, leading to a differential condition a(x) = (alpha/beta) b(x) + 0.5 b(x) b'(x)

Concrete example: for dx = x^gamma [1 + gamma/2 x^{gamma-1} dt + dW] the ergodic transformation solves f'(x)=1/b(x)=x^{-gamma} giving f(x)=x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma)+C, i.e. power utility-like transformation

Interpretation: common utility forms (log, CRRA power) arise as ergodic transformations of particular dynamics; gamma need not be a psychological risk-aversion parameter but a property tied to the dynamics

One can recover a discounted-utility style valuation when the ergodic transformation renders the process with stationary independent increments; solving a functional equation yields exponential discounting V(f(xt0+Delta t)) = beta exp(-alpha Delta t)

Limitations: reliance on asymptotic t->infinity is pre-asymptotic in real life, assumes agents know true dynamics (objective uncertainty), and ignores preferences for early resolution of uncertainty and ambiguity aversion

Extensions: incorporate time-to-convergence preferences by comparing characteristic convergence times and extend framework to model uncertainty and ambiguity aversion as in robust preferences literature

Empirical note: Copenhagen Experiment observed subjects adapt implied utility to render changes ergodic (log for multiplicative, identity for additive), motivating empirical relevance of ergodicity-based representation

Conclusion: axiomatization supplies conditions under which maximizing expected value of an ergodic transformation is normatively equivalent to maximizing long-run time-average wealth growth and clarifies where Ergodicity Economics departs from classical EUT
